issues.description: The problem statement specifies that Animal.messageOnFeed() is abstract and returns a String, but in the solution repository Animal.java defines messageOnFeed() to return FeedResponse. This return-type conflict prevents students from matching the UML and task description.
issues.suggested_fix: Align the return type of messageOnFeed() across all artifacts; either change the solution’s Animal.messageOnFeed() to return String or update the problem statement and UML to use FeedResponse consistently.

issues.description: Within the solution repository, Animal.messageOnFeed() is declared to return FeedResponse, but Goat.java overrides it to return String. These mismatched signatures make the solution code uncompilable.
issues.suggested_fix: Ensure all subclasses override messageOnFeed() with the exact return type declared in Animal. Either change Goat.messageOnFeed() to return FeedResponse or update Animal to return String.

issues.description: The UML and task description specify singFarmSongVerse should take an Animal parameter, but the template’s Farm.java stub declares singFarmSongVerse() with no parameters (the Animal parameter is commented out).
issues.suggested_fix: In the template, change the signature to private void singFarmSongVerse(Animal animal) so it matches the UML and allows printing each animal’s verse.

issues.description: The problem statement and UML specify that messageOnFeed() returns a String, but the solution repository’s Animal class defines messageOnFeed() to return a FeedResponse object and introduces a new FeedResponse class not mentioned in the problem or template. Students expecting to work directly with Strings may be confused by this unexpected wrapper.
issues.suggested_fix: Either change the solution’s messageOnFeed() return type back to String (removing the FeedResponse wrapper) or update the problem statement and template to introduce and explain the FeedResponse class consistently.
